Scheme. 1 Schematic diagram for possible formation pathways of products of the HDMM process. Scheme 1 Fig. 1 (a) The top and side view of Cu-Cr(111) catalyst surface. Orange spheres represent Cu atoms, blue represent Cr atoms, red represent O atoms, respectively. (b) The kMC snapshot of Cu-Cr(111) model under steady states. Blue represent Cr and deep red represent O. Fig 1 Fig. 2 The adsorption models of DMM on the (a) Cu(111) and (b) Cr4O6 of the Cu-Cr(111) catalyst surface. Fig 2 Fig. 3 Calculated Bader charge and the difference charge density differences of (a)Cu-Cr(111) catalyst surface, (b)DMM*-Cu, and (c) DMM*-Cr on the Cu-Cr(111) surface. Blue and yellow represent the electron accumulation and depletion region, respectively. Fig 3 Fig. 4 The structures of (a) DMSu* and (b) C4H7O2-CH2O*. (c) Energy diagram for all possible MGHB, GBL, and BDO formation pathways starting from activation of DMSu*. The number of the elementary steps was shown in Table 3S. The orange, green, and blue lines represent direct C-O bond cleavage mechanism, hydrogenation of ester carbonyl C mechanism, and hydrogenation of ester carbonyl O mechanism, respectively. The dark red lines represent the steps to form products. Lines with different shades indicate different subsequent steps of the intermediate formed by this mechanism. Fig 4 Fig. 5 Energy diagram for all possible BDO formation pathways starting from activation of MGHB*. The meanings of the lines with different colors are mentioned in Fig. 4. Fig 5 Fig. 6 Energy diagram for BDO, GHB, 2-HTHF, and THF formation pathways starting from activation of GBL*. The meanings of the lines with different colors are mentioned in Fig. 4. Fig 6 Fig. 7 The adsorption models and calculated Bader charge of BDO* on the (a) Cu(111) and (b) Cr4O6 of the Cu-Cr(111) catalyst surface. Energy diagram for THF and n-BuOH formation pathways starting from activation of BDO* at (c) Cu(111) surface and (d) Cr4O6 cluster on the Cu-Cr(111) catalyst surface. Green and blue lines represent direct dehydration mechanism and stepwise dehydration mechanism, respectively. Fig 7 Scheme. 2 Flowchart of the method for building and fitting the LHHW model based on DFT and kMC results. Scheme 2 Fig. 8 (a) TOF of each elementary step for R1 under T = 473 K, p = 5 MPa, and n H 2 : n DMM : n DMSu = 200 : 0.95 : 0.05 . (b) DRC for the formation of DMSu at 433 ∼ 513 K (reactions with |DRC| < 0.01 were omitted). The width of the shape represents the absolute DRC value, and the orange/blue-gray color marks positive/negative DRC, respectively. (c) Coverage (θ) of intermediates for R1 on the Cu-Cr(111) surface at T = 433 ∼ 513K. Key Laboratory for Green Chemical Technology of Ministry of Education R&D Center for Petrochemical Technology Tianjin University Tianjin 300072 China 1,4-Butanediol (BDO) is a fine chemical raw material that plays a significant role in the production of degradable plastics. The hydrogenation of dimethyl maleate (HDMM) to BDO is a highly favored technology the industry for its low-cost catalysts and high selectivity. However, the kinetics equation and optimal conditions for HDMM process to BDO on copper-chromium catalysts are still unclear, which has hindered the development of the design of advanced industrial reactors and production processes. Herein, the Cu-Cr(111) surface model was constructed by combining DFT and kMC to investigate the reaction network of the HDMM process. The analysis of the activation barrier and Bader charge revealed that Cu0 and Cr act as the active centers for ester hydrogenation and alcohol hydroxyl cleavage, respectively. The dominant pathways and key intermediates for the formation of γ-butyrolactone (GBL), BDO, and tetrahydrofuran (THF) were claimed by TOF and coverage analysis. Changes in the rate-determining step with temperature for BDO formation were observed by the concepts of degree of rate control. Based on the reaction network, a method was proposed to construct the intrinsic kinetic equation models, which are subjected to nonlinear optimization and linear/nonlinear fitting to obtain relevant parameters. Analysis of the kinetic and thermodynamic properties of reactions in the HDMM process revealed that the higher temperature and total pressure, the lower H2-ester ratio, the higher reaction rates, and different products have different responses to the reaction conditions. Optimal conditions were determined to target different products. This study attempted to span from the microscale to mesoscale, providing theoretical support for novel reactor design for the HDMM process and possibilities for studying the kinetic properties of C4+ complex reaction systems through multi-scale simulation. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Dimethyl maleate Hydrogenation Density functional theory Kinetic Monte Carlo Reaction network Kinetic model Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction 1,4-Butanediol (BDO) is a fine chemical raw material that plays a significant role in the fields of engineering plastics and fibers [1,2]. BDO and its derivatives are used in the production of biodegradable plastics such as polybutylene adipate-co-terephthalate (PBAT) and polybutylene succinate (PBS), which is one of the effective ways to fundamentally address the issue of plastic pollution [3,4]. The process of hydrogenation of dimethyl maleate (DMM) to BDO was first industrialized in the 1980s by Davy McKee, Kvaerner, and Eurodiol [5]. The hydrogenation of dimethyl maleate (HDMM) yields dimethyl succinate (DMSu), which can further be hydrogenated to achieve the co-production of BDO, γ-butyrolactone (GBL), and tetrahydrofuran (THF). GBL is a raw material for the electrolytes of lithium batteries, and THF is a raw material for polyurethane and spandex fibers [6,7]. Copper chromium (Cu-Cr) catalyst, which is an approximate isomolecular combination of copper oxide and copper chromite (CuO/CuCr2O4), performs under 423 ∼ 513K, 2 ∼ 5 MPa, and different space velocities and hydrogen-ester ratios in the HDMM process [8]. It is generally believed that the high activity and selectivity of Cu-Cr catalysts is attributed to Cu0 nanoparticles supported on CuCr2O4 [9]. Turner et al. [10] obtained Cu0 nanoparticles with smaller size (30 ∼ 150 nm to 10 ∼ 30 nm) and larger surface area (4.5 m2/g to 18.5 m2/g) by heating from room temperature to 443K in the presence of reducing gas during the catalyst activation process, which improved the activity. The HDMM process from Davy adopts a two-stage adiabatic bed reactor under 443∼463K, 4.14MPa, n H 2 : n D M M = 301 : 1 , the reaction mainly produces DMSu, GBL, BDO, THF, n-Butanol (n-BuOH), methanol (CH3OH), and H2O. The conversion rate of DMSu is about 94.7 %, and the selectivity of BDO is about 76.5 % [5,8]. Although the process has been industrialized, the high molar ratio of hydrogen to C4+ compounds (abbreviated as H2-ester ratio) leads to high production costs. As shown in Scheme. 1 [11–13], the HDMM process is a strong exothermic reaction (-170.4 kJ/mol) [11]. However, the presence of a large amount of H2, which has a high specific heat capacity (14.3 kJ/(kg·K)), makes the thermal effect of the reaction system not apparent [14]. Ohlinger et al. [15] pointed out that the presence of a large amount of H2 promoted the sintering of active Cu particles, resulting in a rapid decline in catalyst life. Lowering the H2-ester ratio has become an important research direction while ensuring that the reaction proceeds normally. When the H2-ester ratio is reduced, the H2 feed rate will decrease, resulting in a significant increase in system temperature, which makes it difficult to control temperature changes in adiabatic bed reactors [16]. At the same time, the reaction heat carried by H2 will be lost in the process of separation and circulation [17]. Even if the interstage cooler is used to take heat, the efficiency of heat utilization will be reduced [18]. Furthermore, the adiabatic bed reactor limited the production scale of BDO due to its poor heat transfer capacity [19]. An isothermal fixed-bed reactor can ensure that the bed temperature is basically the same by extracting heat directly [20], and the recovered heat can be further utilized through methods like steam generation, which improves the heat levels and utilization efficiency. Steffen et al. [21] and Javaid et al. [22] found that the equilibrium composition of BDO decreases with the increase in temperature, and the isothermal reactor can improve the selectivity of BDO by controlling the temperature. In the design of an isothermal fixed-bed reactor to ensure the conversion rate and BDO selectivity to reach the industrial level, the H2-ester ratio might be appropriately reduced, and the purpose of heat utilization and energy saving can be achieved. Therefore, upgrading adiabatic bed reactors to isothermal bed reactors holds significant importance. The design of isothermal fixed-bed reactors for heterogeneous catalysis can be realized by computational fluid dynamics, but the determination of the reactor size and reaction conditions requires the support of the kinetic equations [23,24]. The evaluation of reaction kinetics is the basis for the design and application of heterogeneous catalytic processes. In general, kinetic equations can be obtained by experimental means. Yang et al. [25] used a fixed-bed tube reactor to study the intrinsic kinetics of dimethyl adipate (DMA) hydrogenation. The power-law kinetic equation model was used to fit the experimental results. The apparent activation barrier of the reaction is 63.6 kJ/mol. One of the most commonly used kinetic models for surface bimolecular reactions is the Langmuir- Hinshelwood- Hougan- Watson (LHHW) model [26]. Chaudhari et al. [27] proposed the rate equations for various reaction steps of hydrogenation of diethyl maleate assuming single site LHHW mechanism based on the integral reactor data. Ahmad et al. [28] prepared K-Cu/ZnO/Cr2O3 catalysts and established the CH3OH production rate rule by the LHHW model. It should be noted that fitting a kinetic model using experimental data alone cannot provide much information about the underlying surface mechanism of a heterogeneous catalyst. Kinetic data must be supported by spectral data that define the composition and structure of the catalyst, as well as all the intermediates involved in making up the elementary steps of the catalytic reaction [29,30]. Based on calculations from previous work and other reports, all possible products and possible reactions are shown in Scheme. 1 [11,12]. Huang et al. [31] reported the presence of 2-hydroxytetrahydrofuran (2-HTHF) and methyl 4-hydroxybutanoate (MGHB). Due to the complexity of the HDMM process involving numerous products, it is difficult to capture the key intermediates of the HDMM process through in-situ characterization, let alone detailed elementary steps. Therefore, if an accurate intrinsic kinetic model is to be obtained, the reaction mechanism of the HDMM process and the action mechanism of Cu and Cr need to be explored in-depth. The multi-scale coupling simulation method of Ab initio kinetic Monte Carlo (kMC) has become increasingly developed and popular in the area of surface catalysis [32]. Herein, a method to construct an intrinsic kinetic model was developed based on the reaction network of the HDMM process obtained by density functional theory (DFT) and kMC calculation. In this paper, the surface model of Cu-Cr catalysts was constructed by DFT combined with transmission electron microscope (TEM), x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and in situ pyridine infrared, and the reaction mechanism of the HDMM process was calculated. The reaction network under typical conditions was constructed using kMC calculation. According to the information on turnover frequency (TOF) and coverage, the LHHW model of intrinsic kinetic equations of four key reactions in the HDMM process were constructed. It is hoped to provide direct support for the design of the isothermal fixed-bed reactor for the HDMM process. 2 Model and computational methods 2.1 Calculation method All spin-polarized DFT is calculated by using Vienna ab initio software package (VASP) based on the plane wave basis set [33]. The electron-ion interaction is described by the projected enhanced wave (PAW) method and a plane-wave basis set with a cutoff kinetic energy of 400 eV was employed [34]. The density of Monkhorst-Pack k-point samplings was kept at ∼0.04 Å-1 [35,36]. In all calculations, the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) exchange correlation (XC) functional developed by Perdew, Burke and Ernzerhof (PBE) is used [37]. The tolerance of the self-consistent field (SCF) is 10–5 eV, and the maximum force convergence criterion is 0.03 eV/Å. By adding a pair of interaction terms to the Kohn-Sham energy, including the dispersion correction of the van der Waals interaction, the DFT-D3 method with Becke-Johnson damping function is adopted and extended for periodic calculations [38]. The magnetic moments calculated by spin polarization are 3.0 for chromium atoms and 0.0 for other atoms. To account for the strong correlation between the d electrons of Cr, the three-dimensional state of Cr was corrected using Hubbard + U (DFT + U). Based on extensive literature review [39–41], the U and J parameters were consider as 5.0 eV and 1.0 eV, respectively. The transition states were obtained by the "climbing-image" nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) and Dimer methods [42]. The validity of each transition state was confirmed by a single imaginary frequency of the normal modes at the saddle point. After the correction to zero-point energy (ZPE), the relative energy was calculated for each elementary step [43]. The detailed calculation method for ZPE and Gibbs free energy was described in the Supporting Information. The kMC simulation was performed with the Kinetix module based on the CARLOS program implemented in the Material Studio 8.0 software package [44]. Calculations for the kMC simulation were performed using the variable step size method [45]. The detailed kMC calculation methods for the adsorption rate, the pre-exponential factor of surface reaction and diffusion, the rate constant for gas desorption, the interactions between species (calculated in Table 1S), the coverage (θ) of each species, and the turnover frequency (TOF) of the elementary step were all displayed in the Supporting Information (Kinetic Monte Carlo modeling). The system was simulated for 5000 ms with a 1 ms step, which was sufficient to achieve the steady state under the provided conditions [46]. 2.2 Surface model This study focuses on elucidating the detailed mechanism of the HDMM process on industrial Cu-Cr catalysts. It is necessary to consider the mechanism of both Cu and Cr before modeling. Generally speaking, industrial Cu-Cr catalysts consist of Cu0 particles uniformly distributed on amorphous Cr-containing support, with an average size of approximately 10 nm and a maximum size exceeding 30 nm [47,48]. The surface active sites and surface models of Cu-Cr catalysts have been extensively studied. Chiang et al. [49] prepared CuO-CuCr2O4 catalysts and found that the Cu atoms in the first shell changed from Cu-O to Cu-Cu after the catalytic reaction. Cu0 particles are important active components on the catalyst surface and mainly expose the Cu(111) surface. Torres et al. [50] found that the Cu-Cr catalyst has smaller CuO nanoparticles, resulting in the highest Cu0 dispersion (27 %) after activation. XPS analysis showed that partially Cu0 particles are covered after reduction treatment due to Cr enrichment on the surface, thereby reducing the number of active sites. Ma et al. [51] showed that the activated catalysts have (111), (200), and (220) planes of Cu by X-ray diffraction (XRD). The selection of the surface model needs to consider the specific composition and structural morphology of the catalyst. Herein, all catalytic experiments were performed using commercially available catalysts E 403T supplied by BASF AG, which is particularly useful for vapor phase hydrogenation reactions, such as hydrogenation of dimethyl maleate, containing 37 %wt Cu and 31 %wt Cr. The high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) experiment was carried out immediately after catalyst activation. As shown in Fig. 1S(a, b), the Cu(111) surface was present in the freshly reduced catalyst, which is consistent with previous research. The EDS mapping in Fig. 1S(c) showed that the Cu and Cr elements are not evenly distributed, with Cr appearing to be mainly distributed at the edges of Cu0 nanoparticles and co-existing with O and Cu elements, which may be the reduced CuCr2O4. Fig. 2S is derived from the XRD spectrum of the Cu-Cr catalyst by Xiao et al. [52], showing that Cu0 particles are mainly oriented with the (111) surface. Liu et al. [53] found that Cu in the commercial catalyst Cu 1800P was completely reduced and remained metallic at 473K and 573K. In-situ XAFS results indicate that Cu+ may not be an active site in hydrogenation. Therefore, Cu0 should be considered as the active site for the hydrogenation reaction when studying the reaction mechanism, and the Cu(111) surface should be selected as the model of the Cu-Cr catalyst used in the HDMM process. Previous studies have demonstrated that Cr oxide exists as a support, which has strong interactions with Cu0 particles and the ability to stabilize them. Liu et al. [53] pointed out that Cr species produced by partial decomposition of copper chromite covered the active Cu site when the reduction temperature was increased. The Cr 2p3/2 spectrum in Fig. 3S showed the presence of Cr2O3 and spinel CuCr2O4. It should be noted that the peak signal strength of Cr2O3 is weaker than that of CuCr2O4, which may indicate that a small amount of Cr2O3 exists on the catalyst surface, consistent with the findings of Zhang et al. [54]. Zhu et al. [55] found that Cu0 is the active site for GBL hydrogenation or BDO dehydrogenation by characterizing Cu/SiO2 catalysts. The strong Lewis acid site is the key to the dehydration of BDO/2-HTHF to form THF/2,3-dihydrofuran, which has Cu-O-M structures (M is Cu or other additive). It can be found that Lewis acid sites may affect the dehydration of BDO. Fig. 4S showed in situ pyridine-FT-IR spectra after the reduction of E 430T, which can characterize the acid properties of the Cu-Cr catalyst. The Lewis acid sites correspond to the 1445 cm-1 band and are attributed to pyridine coordination binding to accessible Cr3+ species [56]. It can be found that the vibration peaks are not obvious, which may indicate that acid sites on the surface are weak and the number is small. The peak area of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites decreased at 323 ∼ 623K and 523 ∼ 623K, respectively, which may indicate that Lewis acid sites have a stronger ability to adsorb probe molecules. Colley et al. [57] pointed out that Lewis acid site properties of the Cr2O3 phase may be a key factor to improve the selectivity of ethyl acetate. In general, the surface of the E 403T catalyst is dominated by Cu0 after reduction activation. The Lewis acid site may mainly come from Cu-O-Cr species, which have strong adsorption capacity for reactant molecules. Due to the small amount of Cr oxides on the surface, it is feasible to consider adding small CrOx clusters on the basis of the Cu(111) surface model, ensuring that the influences of both Cu and Cr on the reaction can be taken into account in the study of the reaction mechanism while keeping the computational cost within an acceptable range. Therefore, the Cu-Cr(111) catalyst model was constructed on a Cu(111) surface through a CrOx cluster (Cr4O6). Cu(111) is not only the surface most exposed to Cu nanoparticles but also widely used in the study of hydrogenation reaction mechanism. The inspiration for placing CrOx cluster models on the Cu(111) surface comes from previous studies. Bai et al. [58] constructed Al4O6 clusters on the Cu(111) surface to study the effect of γ-Al2O3 on the CO hydrogenation process. Al4O6 clusters were primarily involved in the formation of the by-product ethanol. Shen et al. [59] prepared CrOx-Cu reverse phase catalyst with nanoporous structure by dealloying, which showed excellent catalytic performance for the reduction of CO2. The DFT calculation on the CrOx-Cu(111) surface showed that the synergistic effect of Cr2O3 clusters and Cu promoted CO2 reduction. Our previous work constructed the Zn6O7H7/Cu(111) surface model and focused on the influence of Cu-ZnO synergism on the HDMM process. Herein, the purpose of constructing the CrOx cluster model is mainly to study the influence of a small amount of Lewis acid sites in contact with Cu0 particles on the reaction. Within the acceptable computational capacity, the Cu-Cr(111) surface with Cr4O6 as the Lewis acid site cluster model is a reasonable choice. The Cr4O6 cluster structure may exist in various configurations. The formation energy of 5 kinds of clusters was calculated by DFT, and it was found that the cluster formation energy of T d symmetry was the lowest [60] in Fig. 5S. The surface energies of the Cu-Cr(111) surface models were also calculated using Equation 25S, which results from the combination of different configurations of Cr4O6 clusters with Cu(111). The surface energy of the Cu(111) surface model is calculated to be 1.81 J/m2, which is close to the experimental value of 1.83 J/m2 [61], confirming the validity of the calculation results. The calculated surface energies of the Cu-Cr(111) surfaces were shown in Fig. 5S, from which it can be observed that the stability order of different configurations of the Cu-Cr(111) surfaces is T d > C 2 h ≈ D 2 h > D 4 h > D 2 h . Thus, the T d symmetry structure remains the most stable Cu-Cr(111) surface model, with a surface energy of 1.51 J/m2. Therefore, T d can be regarded as the Cr4O6 cluster on the Cu(111) surface, as shown in Fig. 5S. The selection of the position and orientation of the Cr4O6 cluster results in the lowest energy, as shown in Fig. 1 (a). The Cr atom forms a 3-coordination tetrahedral structure. It should be noted that the Cr4O6 cluster is regarded as surface amorphous Cr2O3 structures that provide Lewis acidic sites for Cr3+ formation [58,62]. The surface is modeled by a three-layer slab with a 6 × 5 supercell, and a vacuum slab of 15 Å in the Z direction is employed. The surface gives the lattice parameters of a = 15.170 Å, b = 12.642 Å, c = 19.129 Å, α = β = 90°, γ = 120°. The bottom one layer is fixed in the bulk positions while the upper two layers as well as the Cr4O6 cluster are allowed to relax during geometry optimization and transition state (TS) search. The adsorption sites on the Cu-Cr(111) binary catalyst surface were involved during the HDMM reaction, which were labeled as Cutop, Cubridge, Cuhcp, Cufcc, and Cr, respectively. All the kMC calculations in this work use the lattice-gas model to describe the surface reaction system. The surface of the Cu(111) surface was represented by a two-dimensional hexagonal periodic model with 128 × 128 lattice points that contained top and hollow sites, as shown in Fig. 1(b). In addition, the Cr4O6 cluster containing Cr sites is added according to the CrOx cluster model, and Cr4O6 cluster were randomly distributed on the Cu(111) layer. In order to obtain more accurate results in kMC calculation, the active sites of the E 403T catalyst after activation were quantitatively analyzed. For the surface Cu site, the number of Cu atoms on the surface was 5.68 × 10–4 mol/gcat measured by N2O-H2 chemical titration and Equation 22S. The Cu-O-Cr interface sites in Cr4O6 cluster were treated as Lewis acid sites. The results of in situ pyridine-FT-IR spectra were quantitatively analyzed according to the peak area, and the number of Lewis acid sites on the surface was 0.06 × 10–4 mol/gcat calculated by Equation 23S. It can be found that the number of Lewis acid sites is about two orders of magnitude less than the number of surface Cu sites, and the lattice-gas model in kMC calculation can be constructed according to this ratio. In our previous job, the Zn6O7H7/Cu(111) kinetix module for the HDMM process was constructed by similar approach [36]. Liu et al. [63] constructed CeO2/Cu2O/Cu(111) kinetix module for CH4 selective oxidation. 3 Results and discussion The hydrogenation of dimethyl maleate (HDMM) process is categorized into different steps including (1) dimethyl succinate (DMSu) formation via DMM, (2) GBL formation via DMSu, (3) BDO formation via methyl 4-hydroxybutanoate (MGHB), (4) BDO formation via GBL, (5) THF formation via BDO, and so on. DFT calculation data for all possible 108 elementary steps were listed in Table 2S, where the activation barriers and reaction heats are the results after zero-point energy (ZPE) correction. Frequency analysis was used to validate the optimized transition state (TS) structures. For kMC calculations, the optimal pathways for the HDMM process were obtained under typical conditions. The variation of TOF, coverage, and rate-determining step under different temperatures, pressures, and H2-ester ratios were studied, and kinetic equations were constructed. The results of the pre-exponential factors of the elementary steps in the kMC simulation were listed in Table 3S. The orders of magnitude of these pre-exponential factors are close to the previous study [64]. 3.1 The detailed reaction mechanism of HDMM process on the Cu-Cr(111) surface 3.1.1 DMSu formation via DMM In order to study the detailed mechanism of the HDMM process, the adsorption properties of DMM were first studied. Fig. 2 showed the most stable adsorption configuration of DMM on the Cu-Cr(111) surface, where DMM* is adsorbed parallel to Cu(111) or close to Cr4O6. To facilitate the discussion, two ester carbonyl groups are labeled in Fig. 2(a), C=O is labeled C1/O1 and C2/O2, and C=C interacting with Cutop is labeled C3/C4. The configuration of DMM* is similar in both positions, and there is strong interaction with the surface. Unlike small molecules, DMM* has at least two adsorption sites on two surfaces. The C=C double bond and the metal Cutop site have π − d interact on both positions, and the C-Cu bond length is 2.140 Å, which is close to the C-Pd bond length of C2H4 on the Pd/Cu(111) surface calculated by Ma et al. [65], indicating that the π − d interaction in DMM is strong. The length of the C=C bond in adsorbed DMM* (1.446 Å) is longer by 0.1 Å compared with that of the gas phase molecule (1.341 Å), and the H-C bond is bent upward relative to the C=C bond, indicating that the adsorption configuration makes C=C activated. On Cu(111) surface, two C=O bonds have p − d interact with Cutop, and O-Cu bond length is about 2.1 Å. On Cr4O6, two C=O bonds have p − d interact with Cr, and the coordination number of the Cr atom increases from three coordination in tetrahedral form to five coordination in tetragonal cone form. The configuration obtained by calculation is reasonable from the explanation of ligand field theory since the 3d/4s/4p electron subshell of Cr3+ contains five empty orbitals. The O-Cr bond lengths were 2.045 Å and 2.063 Å, respectively, indicating that the Cr site has stronger interactions with DMM* than the Cu site. It should be pointed out that when DMM is adsorbed on the Cu-Cr(111) surface far from the Cr site, the bond length of each group and adsorption energy of DMM* are close to that on pure Cu(111) surface (-1.39 eV) [36], which shows that the Lewis acid site composed of a small amount of Cr2O3 has only local effects on the hydrogenation active site of the catalyst. The activation of DMM is the key to trigger a series of subsequent hydrogenation reactions, and it is necessary to explore the properties of its adsorption and activation processes. Fig. 3 showed the Bader charge distribution and difference charge density (DCD) of different structures. On the clean Cu-Cr(111) surface in Fig. 3(a), the charge of Cr atom is +1.44 |e|, and the charge of Cu atom near the Cr4O6 cluster is +0.17 |e|, which indicates the formation of the Cu-O-Cr structure. The Cu atoms surrounding the Cr4O6 cluster have a weak negative charge, which indicates that a small amount of charge may be transferred from Cr to the Cu(111) surface. DCD diagram showed that the charge distribution on Cu surface changes little, which indicates that Cr2O3 has little influence on the electronic properties of Cu particles. The charge distribution of DMM*-O-Cutop was shown in Fig. 3(b). The charge of Cu atom interacting with C=C decreases by 0.12 |e| after DMM* adsorbed, and the charge of C atoms on C=C are -0.15 |e| and -0.21 |e|, indicating that the charge of Cutop is transferred to C and C-Cu chemical bond is formed. Similar results were found for Cu atoms interacting with carbonyl O (+0.17 |e| and +0.19 |e|), indicating that O1 and O2 formed O-Cu bonds with Cutop. The charge of Cu atom near Cr4O6 cluster is basically unchanged compared with clean Cu-Cr(111) surface, which indicates that DMM* adsorption has little effect on Cr4O6 cluster. In Fig. 3(c), all the carbonyl O atoms in DMM* interact with Cr atoms, and its positive charge increases to +1.61 |e|, indicating that charge is transferred to DMM*. DCD diagram also showed that the charge distribution of the Cr4O6 cluster changes significantly, which indicates that DMM* interacts with the Cr4O6 cluster. The adsorption energy of DMM on the Cu(111) surface is -1.44 eV, which is much lower than that near the Cr4O6 cluster (-2.09 eV), which may be due to the configuration change of the Cr4O6 cluster before and after adsorption. Therefore, it is necessary to further study the activation barrier of the reaction to analyze the influence of the Cr4O6 cluster on the hydrogenation reaction. Due to the C=C bond is activated by Cu(111) surface, DMM will first hydrogenate to DMSu, and the reaction equation is R1 DMM + H2 → DMSu. Table 2S showed the activation barriers and reaction heats of elementary steps S1 ∼ S2. The structures of the initial, final and transition states of the process were shown in Fig. 6S. H2 can be first adsorbed and dissociated on the surface of Cu-Cr(111), and the heat release of the reaction is 0.52 eV. Dumesic et al. [66] measured the dissociative adsorption heat of H2 on the Cu/SiO2 catalysts to be 0.56 ± 0.3 eV, which is close to the calculated result in this paper (0.52 eV). H2 atom can be dissociated on the Cuhcp or Cufcc sites, and the diffusion activation barrier of H* between hollow sites is 0.11 eV. The results are consistent with previous studies. For DMM* adsorbed on Cu(111) surface, H* may attack C atom in C=C double bond of DMM* to form RCH2-C*HR, the activation barrier of S1 is 0.43 eV, the reaction heat is -0.18 eV, and H* is closer to Cu(111) surface than DMM*. Subsequently, H* at the Cufcc site will continue to attack the RCH2-C*HR to form DMSu*. The activation barrier of S2 (0.71eV) is higher than that of S1, and the reaction heat is -0.54 eV. Both hydrogenation steps are exothermic reactions. The adsorption energy of DMSu is -1.14 eV, which is significantly reduced compared with DMM, since there is no longer π − d interaction between C=C bond and Cutop after hydrogenation. For DMM* adsorbed on Cr4O6 cluster, it can be found that the TS configurations are similar to that on Cu(111) surface. The activation barriers of the elementary steps are 0.50 eV and 0.76 eV, respectively, higher than that on the Cu(111) surface, which may be due to the distance from the Cu(111) surface after adsorption on the Cr4O6 cluster. Fig. 3(c) revealed that the charge on the C1 atom decreases from +1.41 |e| to +1.35 |e| after adsorption of DMM* on Cr4O6, which may not be conducive to the attack of H* to the ester group. Conversely, the difference in charge on the C=O bond decreases, which may favor the cleavage of C=O bond. Therefore, the Cr4O6 cluster may not have a clear promoting effect on the hydrogenation reaction. Besides, considering that the in situ pyridine-FT-IR spectra demonstrate a very low number of Cr sites acting as Lewis acids, this study does not consider the Cr4O6 cluster as an active site for the hydrogenation and will discuss it in the context of the BDO dehydration. 3.1.2 GBL formation via DMSu The mechanism of hydrogenation reduction of ester compounds to alcohols can be divided into three pathways of direct C-O bond cleavage, hydrogenation of the ester carbonyl carbon atom, and hydrogenation of the ester carbonyl oxygen atom [67,68]. In this study, three pathways of all esters involved in DMM hydrogenation on Cu-Cr(111) surface were discussed in detail. The process consists of R2 DMSu + 2H2 → MGHB + CH3OH, R3 DMSu + 2H2 → GBL + 2CH3OH, and R4 DMSu + 4H2 → BDO + 2CH3OH. The initial, transition, and final state structures of steps S3 ∼ S23 were shown in Fig. 7S. The adsorption configuration of DMSu was shown in Fig. 4 (a), where O1 and O2 are anchored at two Cutop sites, and the O-Cu bond length is 2.207 Å and 2.266 Å, respectively, which increases by more than 0.1 Å compared with the distance between DMM* and the surface. DMSu* breaks the C-O bond on Cu-Cr(111) surface and occurs the hydrogenysis process. Since the surface is covered with a large number of H*, H-assisted DMSu* activation may occur on the surface. C4H7O2-CO* and CH3O* are formed in S3, where the methoxy group is located at the Cuhcp site, and the carbonyl C and O in C4H7O2-CO* act at the Cutop site, respectively. The activation barrier of S3 is 1.27 eV, and the reaction heat is 0.30 eV. The transition state vibrational frequency of S3 is 221i cm-1, which is consistent with the characterization results by Yu et al. [69]. S4 and S6 are reactions in which C=O is activated by H*, which attacks the C1 and O1 atoms, respectively. It can be found that the activation energy (0.71 eV to 1.19 eV) and reaction heat (0.44 eV to 0.63 eV) of the reaction of S4 are lower than that of S6. Pieck et al. [70] revealed that the apparent activation barrier of C=O bond hydrogenation of methyl oleate on RuSnB/Al2O3 catalyst is 1.20 eV by kinetic experiments, higher than the barrier of S4, which may be attributed to differences in metals. Wang et al. [68] investigated the mechanism of DMO hydrogenation on Cu9/CeO2 by DFT and found that the acetyl O can attack H* to form C(-OH)-CH2OH with an activation energy barrier of 1.19 eV, validating the reasonableness of the calculated result of S5. The ester carbonyl carbon hydrogenation step S4–1 was also calculated occurring at Cr sites, as shown in Fig. 7S. The activation barrier of S4–1 is 0.85 eV, higher than that of S4, and the reaction is endothermic by 0.40 eV, which indicates that Cr sites do not significantly promote the ester group hydrogenation. C4H7O2-CHO-CH3O* and C4H7O2-COH-CH3O* are formed after H* attacks DMSu*, respectively. S5 and S7 are C-O bond cleavage steps, and the activation barrier of C-O bond cleavage for C4H7O2-CHO-CH3O* (S5) is reduced to 0.22 eV, which is 6 times smaller than that of S3, indicating that H* can indeed assist DMSu* activation. C4H7O2-CO* immediately reacts with H* (S8 and S9) to form C4H7O2-CHO* and C4H7O2-COH*. C4H7O2-CHO* is hydrogenated to form C4H7O2-CH2O* and C4H7O2-CHOH* by S10 and S11, with barriers of 0.32 eV and 0.66 eV, respectively. C4H7O2-COH* forms C4H7O2-CHOH* from S12 with an activation barrier of 0.50 eV. It can be found that the activation barrier of H* attacking C1 is lower than that of H* attacking O1, which may indicate that C1 atom in C=O is more easily activated by H* than O1. C4H7O2-CHOH* can easily react with H* (S14) to form MGHB with an barrier of 0.50 eV. From a thermodynamic point of view, C4H7O2-CH2O* is an easier intermediate to be formed than C4H7O2-CHOH*. C4H7O2-CH2O* may react with H* (S13) to form MGHB*, which has a barrier of 1.13 eV and exothermicity of 0.09 eV. The activation barrier of S13 on Cu-Cr catalyst is higher than that on Cu-ZnO catalyst (0.75 eV), which indicates that it is difficult to form alcohol hydroxyl group on pure Cu(111) surface. In addition to hydrogenation, C4H6O2-CH2O* can also occur cyclization reaction [71,72] (S15) by attacking C2 with O1 to form C4H6O2-CH3O-r*, with an activation barrier of 0.53 eV, lower than that of S13, and an endothermic of 0.30 eV. Another C=O bond in C4H6O2-CH3O-r* can be destroyed, and O2 forms new O2-Cu bond at Cuhcp site with a bond length of approximately 2.03 Å, while O1 will leave the hollow site and form new C2-O1 bond with a bond length of 1.426 Å, close to the typical C-O bond length. The transition state of S15 with the carbonyl oxygen approaching the Cu surface, transitioning from Cutop to Cuhcp site. The methoxy group in C4H6O2-CH3O-r* can approach the Cu (111) surface, causing the C2-O bond to elongate from 1.403 Å to 1.463 Å, leading to the cleavage of the C2-O bond through S16 to form GBL* and CH3O*, with the methoxy group adsorbed at the Cuhcp site. The activation barrier of S16 is 0.42 eV with exothermicity of 0.20 eV. It should be noted that C4H6O2-CH2O* also contains another ester group, where C2 can react with H* to form C3H7O-CHO-CH2O* through S17, with a barrier of 0.61 eV lower than S3 (0.71 eV), possibly due to the closer distance C4H6O2-CH2O* to the Cu-Cr(111) surface. O1 and O2 are located at the Cuhcp and Cubirdge sites in C3H7O-CHO-CH2O* respectively, and R-CH2O* needs to first react with H* through S18 to form the alcohol hydroxyl group, with a barrier of 1.00 eV. The ester bond in C3H7O-CHO-CH3O* can be cleavage easily (S19) to form GHB* and CH3O* after conformational change, with barrier of 0.13 eV. 4-hydroxybutyraldehyde (GHB) may desorb from the surface, but its aldehyde carbonyl group is highly active, allowing C2 and O2 to occur S20 and S21 to form C3H7O-CH2O* and C3H7O-CHOH* with activation barriers of 0.33 eV and 0.84 eV, respectively. From a thermodynamic perspective, C3H7O-CH2O* is more likely to be formed. C3H7O-CH2O* and C3H7O-CHOH* continue to occur hydrogenation through S22 and S23 to form BDO*, with an activation barrier of 0.95 eV. Overall, the mechanism of hydrogenation of ester carbonyl carbon atom in DMSu is thermodynamically favorable. Obviously, C4H7O2-CH2O* is an important intermediate in DMSu hydrogenation, as shown in Fig. 4(b). O1 is located at the hollow site, and the length of O1-Cu bond is 2.03 ∼ 2.06 Å. O2 is located at the Cutop site with a distance of 2.309 Å, which is longer than the normal O-Cu bond [73], indicating that the interaction between the O2 and Cu surfaces is weak. O1 and C2 react with H* lead to the formation of MGHB and BDO, respectively, and C2 reacts with O1 lead to the formation of GBL. The energy diagram of the reaction S3 ∼ S23 was shown in Fig. 4(c). From the thermodynamic point of view, the tendency of C4H7O2-CH2O* to form the three substances is MGHB < BDO < GBL. The removal of CH3OH from the surface is also an important step in the process. CH3O* adsorbed at Cuhcp site can diffuse to adjacent Cufcc site with a barrier of 0.14 eV, and can form CH3OH through S69 with an energy barrier of 1.09 eV. The transition state of S69 exhibits an imaginary frequency of 1072i cm-1, which is similar to previous study [74]. 3.1.3 BDO formation via MGHB MGHB can continue to hydrogenate to produce BDO, but this intermediate product is not considered to be one of the main products. The reaction of MGHB hydrogenation is R5 MGHB + 2H2 → BDO + CH3OH. The initial, transition, and final state structures of S24 ∼ S30 involved in MGHB hydrogenation were shown in Fig. 8S. The stable adsorption configuration of MGHB is shown in FS13 in Fig. 7S. The distance between H atom in the hydroxyl group of γ-C and O2 atom is 1.662 Å, which accords with the length of intramolecular hydrogen bond [75]. Similar to the mechanism of DMSu hydrogenation, direct C-O bond cleavage (S24) or H-assisted activation (S25 and S26) occurred on the Cu-Cr(111) surface. C3H7O-CO* and CH3O* are formed by directly C-O bond cleavage, with a barrier of 1.11 eV, which is lower than that of DMSu*. C3H7O-CO* can form GHB* and C3H7O-COH* by hydrogenation of S28 and S29, respectively, with activation barriers of 0.44 eV and 0.66 eV, which may indicate that GHB* is more easily formed. MGHB is attacked by H* at the position C2 or O2, forming C3H7O-CHO-CH3O* or C3H7O-COH-CH3O*, with reaction barriers of 1.04 eV and 1.25 eV, resulting in C-O bond breaking (S25 and S26).The mechanism of further hydrogenation to BDO* after the formation of GHB* and C3H7O-COH* has been discussed in Section 3.1.2. The energy diagram of S24 ∼ S30 is shown in Fig. 5 . It should be pointed out that the activation barriers of H-assisted MGHB activation are higher than those of DMSu, which indicates that MGHB hydrogenation is more difficult from the perspective of thermodynamics. 3.1.4 BDO formation via GBL GBL is one of the main products obtained by HDMM, and the hydrogenation of GBL may form BDO, GHB, 2-HTHF, and THF. The adsorption energy of GBL on the Cu-Cr(111) surface is -0.87 eV, which is lower than that of DMM (-1.50 eV) and DMSu (-1.14 eV). The carbonyl group in GBL will be adsorbed at Cutop site, where O2 atom and Cutop site form the O2-Cu bond with a bond length of 2.274 Å, which is longer than that of DMSu (2.207 Å), indicating that GBL is not easily adsorbed on the surface. BDO will be formed if the intraring C-O bond in GBL is cleaved, leading to R6 GBL + 2H2 → BDO occurs. The direct C-O bond cleavage mechanism corresponds to S31, with an activation barrier of 1.12 eV, and endothermic by 0.55 eV. C2H4-CO-CH2O* is hydrogenated by S32 to form C3H7O-CO* with an activation barrier of 0.99 eV. Ester carbonyl carbon atom hydrogenation mechanism corresponds to S33 and S34, H* attacks the C2 atom of carbonyl group of GBL*, and C3H6O-CHO-r* is formed, with an endothermic of 0.2 eV and an activation barrier of 0.96 eV, which is lower than that of direct ring-opening. The out-of-ring C-O bond length in C3H6O-CHO-r* increases from 1.230 Å to 1.376 Å, while the intraring C-O bond length increases from 1.353 Å to 1.490 Å, indicating that the conjugation effect within the ester group is disrupted. It can be found that GBL* changes from being parallel to being vertical to the Cu-Cr(111) surface in IS and TS of S33, while the distance between O1 atom and Cu(111) surface decreases from 2.664 Å to 2.136 Å. The activation barrier of S33–1 is 1.00 eV occurring at Cr sites, slightly higher than that of S33, and the reaction is endothermic by 0.38 eV, indicating that Cr sites also do not significantly promote the hydrogenation process of GBL. As shown in Fig. 6 , the activation barrier for the ring-opening step (S34) of C3H6O-CHO-r* is only 0.54 eV, which is lower than the activation barrier for the direct breaking of the intraring C-O bond. This trend is consistent with the patterns observed in DMSu and MGHB hydrogenolysis. The hydrogenation mechanism of the ester carbonyl oxygen atom corresponds to S35 and S36. The activation barrier for S35 is 1.03 eV and is a strongly endothermic reaction (0.97 eV), which proves that O2 atom of GBL is difficult to combine with H*. The structure formed by the ring-opening of GBL* may be C2H4-CO-CH2O*, C2H4-CHO-CH2O*, and C2H4-COH-CH2O*. For these structures, O1/O2/C2 will occupy at least two Cu sites, with O1 generally adsorbed at the hollow site, which may depend on the position of the surrounding H*. O1/O2/C2 will be sequentially attacked by H*, ultimately forming two alcohol hydroxyl groups, whose elementary steps were calculated separately (S20∼S23, S28∼S30, S36∼S44). The activation barrier for the hydrogenation of R-CH2O* is 0.88 ∼ 1.09 eV, while the activation barrier at C2 atom is 0.14 ∼ 0.44 eV. The hydrogenation will preferentially occur at C2 after the ring-opening of GBL from a thermodynamic perspective. Therefore, the GBL* hydrogenation may prefer to forming C2H4-CH2O-CH2O*, where O1 and O2 can react with H* to form BDO*, with activation barriers of 1.04 eV and 0.95 eV (S40 and S22), respectively. GHB* may also be formed during the ring-opening and hydrogenation of GBL* according to reaction R7 GBL + H2 → GHB. GHB* can either occur hydrogenation, or react with BDO* on the surface to form acetal, which results in reduced product purity. The O2 and C2 atoms of C3H6O-CHO-r* and C3H6O-COH-r* can react with H* to form 2-hydroxytetrahydrofuran (2-HTHF) (S45 and S46), with activation barriers of 0.54 eV and 0.45 eV, respectively. The formation of 2-HTHF follows R8 GBL + H2 → 2-HTHF. Through the reverse step of S47 (S47r), 2-HTHF can occur ring-opening to form C2H4-CHOH-CH2O*, which can be further hydrogenated to BDO*. The activation barrier of S47r is only 0.40 eV, indicating the low stability of 2-HTHF. Huang et al. [31] found that the liquid-phase hydrogenation of GBL over Cu0.1Co0.9/TiO2 catalyst in 1,4-dioxane environment might proceed via 2-HTHF intermediate. However, there are scarce reports regarding the formation of 2-HTHF on commonly used Cu-based catalysts. THF can be formed through the out-of-ring C-O bond cleavage rather than ring-opening after the formation of C3H6O-CHO-r*, C3H6O-COH-r*, or 2-HTHF*. The formation of THF follows R9 GBL + 2H2 → THF + H2O. Multiple pathways exist for the cleavage of the out-of-ring C-O bond. The O2 atom in C3H6O-CHO-r* can directly dissociate (S48), resulting in C3H6O-CH-r* adsorbed at Cutop site and O* adsorbed at hollow site, with an activation barrier of 1.53 eV. The out-of-ring C-O bond of C3H6O-CHO-r* can also attacked by H* (S49). The formation of O2-H bond occurs simultaneously with the cleavage of C2-O2 bond, forming C3H6O-CH-r* and OH*. The activation barrier of S49 (1.68 eV) is higher than that of S48, indicating that H* does not facilitate the cleavage of the out-of-ring C-O bond on the Cu(111) surface. C3H6O-COH-r* can occur similar steps (S50 ∼ S51) to form C3H6O-C-r*, with barriers of 0.68 eV and 1.11 eV respectively. 2-HTHF* can form C3H6O-CH-r* (S52 ∼ S53) with barriers of 1.10 eV and 1.34 eV after hydrogenation. The C2 atom in C3H6O-C-r* can react with H* on the Cu(111) surface (S54) to form C3H6O-CH-r* with a barrier of 0.59 eV. C3H6O-CH-r* can further react with H* (S55) to finally form THF*, with a barrier of 0.34 eV and exothermicity of -0.78 eV. Notably, the barrier for GBL* forming THF* on Cu(111) surface is significantly higher than that for BDO*, indicating that Cu0 may not be the primary site for THF formation on Cu-Cr catalysts. The O* atom at the hollow site can react with H* to form OH* (S71) with a barrier of 0.51 eV, and OH* can be hydrogenated to H2O* through S72 with a higher barrier (1.00 eV). The initial, transition, and final state structures of S31 ∼ S55 involved in GBL hydrogenation were shown in Fig. 9S. 3.1.5 THF & n-BuOH formation via BDO BDO can continue to occur dehydration and deep hydrogenation reactions to form THF and n-BuOH on the Cu-Cr catalyst surface with R10 BDO → THF + H2O and R11 BDO + H2 → n-BuOH + H2O. The initial, transition, and final state structures of steps S56 ∼ S67 and S1-Cr ∼ S12-Cr involved in the dehydration of BDO were shown in Fig. 10S. The mechanism of BDO dehydration can be classified into stepwise dehydration and direct dehydration. BDO can be adsorbed on the Cu-Cr(111) surface as shown in Fig. 7 (a, b). BDO* can form intramolecular hydrogen bonds with bond lengths of 1.6 ∼ 1.8 Å, characteristic of classical intramolecular hydrogen bonds. The intramolecular hydrogen bond may facilitate the abstraction of an H atom from one -OH group by another, thereby completing the dehydration of BDO. As shown in Fig. 7(c), steps S56 and S58 correspond to the direct dehydration mechanism, where C-O bond cleavage occurs simultaneously with H atom abstraction from another -OH group, directly forming H2O*. For step S56, a new C-O bond forms during dehydration, directly forming THF* with an barrier of 1.93 eV and negligible heat change. S58 forms C3H6O-CH2* with an activation barrier of 1.99 eV. C3H6O-CH2* occurs cyclization reaction (S63) to form THF*, with an activation barrier of 1.35 eV and a reaction heat of -0.17 eV. It should be pointed out that C3H7O-CH2O* can also occur -OH group dissociation and cyclize to form THF* and OH* (S60) with a barrier of 1.52 eV, or occur H*-assisted -OH group dissociation to directly form H2O* (S62) with a barrier of 1.50 eV. H* can originate from the reverse reaction of C3H6O-CH2O* hydrogenation (S22). The stepwise dehydration mechanism corresponds to S57, where the -OH group detaches from BDO* to form C3H6O-CH2*, with an activation barrier of 1.72 eV and with an endothermic heat of 0.41 eV. Similar to the direct dehydration mechanism, C3H6O-CH2O* can dissociate to C3H6O-CH2* through S59 and S61, with reaction barriers of 1.58 eV and 1.45 eV respectively. C3H6O-CH2* and C3H7O-CH2* are located on the Cu(111) surface of Cu-Cr catalysts and can react with surface H* to form n-BuOH* (S64 ∼ S67). The R-CH2 group of C3H6O-CH2* can be hydrogenated through S64 to form C3H7-CH2O* with a barrier of 0.59 eV and exothermicity of 0.78 eV. The R-CH2O group can be hydrogenated through S65 to form C3H7-CH2* with a barrier of 1.23 eV and an endothermic heat of 0.18 eV. From a thermodynamic perspective, C3H6O-CH2* is more likely to occur hydrogenation at the R-CH2 group. C3H7-CH2O* and C3H7O-CH2* continue hydrogenation to form n-BuOH* through S66 and S67, with barriers of 1.16 eV and 0.83 eV, respectively. It can be found that it is difficult for dehydration of BDO* on the Cu(111) surface, and the barriers of alcohol hydroxyl dissociation are much higher than that of ester hydrogenation. It was calculated that the dissociation of methanol on the Cu(111) surface is also more than 1.8 eV, indicating that it is difficult for -OH group to dissociate on pure Cu surface. However, previous studies have shown that a significant proportion of THF is formed during the HDMM process, indicating that Cu(111) surface may not be the active site for BDO dehydration. Combined with the analysis in Section 2.2, it is believe that the fracture of -OH groups in BDO may require the support of Lewis acid sites. Therefore, the mechanism Cr site must be taken into account. The adsorption energy of BDO on Cr4O6 reaches -1.62 eV as shown in Table 2S, indicating that Cr site exhibit much stronger anchoring effects compared to the Cu site. Consequently, BDO species likely preferentially adsorb on the Cu-O-Cr structures at the interface with Cu particle. Fig. 7(a, b) showed the Bader charges of BDO* adsorbed on Cu(111) and Cr4O6. When BDO* is adsorbed on the Cu(111) surface, the Cr site carries a charge of +1.40 |e|, while the O2 atom carries -1.22 |e|. After BDO*-Cr adsorption on Cr4O6, the positive charge on the Cr site increases to +1.51 |e|, and the negative charge on the O2 atom increases to -1.58 |e|, indicating charge transfer from Cr to the O2 atom. Meanwhile, the charges on H and O1 atoms remain unchanged, indicating that H atoms on BDO*-Cr are more susceptible to attack by O2 atoms to form H2O, thereby promoting BDO dehydration. The energy diagram of BDO*-Cr on Cr4O6 was shown in Fig. 7(d). Similar to the reaction mechanism on the Cu(111) surface, BDO*-Cr can directly dehydrate through S2-Cr and S4-Cr to form THF* or C3H6O-CH2*, with activation barriers of 1.26 eV and 1.13 eV respectively, significantly lower than that on Cu(111) surface (S56 and S58). The formed THF* and C3H6O-CH2* transfer from Cr4O6 cluster to the Cu(111) surface. H2O*-Cr remains at the Cr site with a desorption energy of 0.75 eV, much higher than on the Cu(111) surface. BDO*-Cr can also occur dehydrogenation through step S1-Cr to form C3H7O-CH2O*-Cr with a barrier of 0.50 eV. Similarly, C3H7O-CH2O*-Cr can form THF* or C3H6O-CH2* through S5-Cr ∼ S8-Cr, with activation barriers exceeding 1.5 eV. For the stepwise dehydration mechanism, BDO*-Cr forms C3H7-CH2* and OH*-Cr through S3-Cr, with an activation barrier of 1.32 eV, slightly higher than that of direct dehydration, with an exothermic heat of 0.04 eV. The energy barrier of -OH dissociation is close to that of Orozco et al. [76]. Since Cr sites can stabilize -OH groups, C3H7-CH2* occupying the hollow site on Cu(111) can have H atoms abstracted by OH*-Cr to form THF* or C3H6O-CH2* through S9 and S10, with barriers of 0.42 eV and 1.33 eV, respectively. OH*-Cr more readily reacts with nearby H* on the Cu(111) surface to form H2O*-Cr, with a barrier of 0.48 eV. In conclusion, alcohol hydroxyl of BDO cleavage on Cr4O6 clusters is significantly easier than that on the Cu(111) surface. The Cr sites at the interface with the Cu surface on Cu-Cr catalysts are likely the active sites for BDO dehydration to form THF and n-BuOH. 3.2 Building and fitting of kinetic model 3.2.1 Determination of dominant path and rate-determining step In heterogeneous catalytic reactions, the LHHW model is considered a commonly used kinetic model. The derivation of the LHHW model is often carried out by assuming reaction mechanisms and rate-determining steps in experimental studies [77,78]. However, the use of numerous ideal assumptions in this process may lead to significant discrepancies with the actual situation. Particularly, the uncertainty in the reaction mechanism requires the establishment of multiple sets of LHHW models based on speculation, which are then fitted to experimental data to obtain a proposed model. This approach may result in different equation forms for the same reaction [77], increasing the experimental workload and potentially reducing the reliability of the model. A thorough understanding of the reaction mechanism contributes to studying reaction kinetics. Herein, the reaction mechanism of the HDMM process was elucidated through DFT calculations, providing guidance for determining the steady-state approximation and rate-determining steps. In previous studies, the elementary step with the highest activation barrier is often regarded as the rate-determining step [79]. However, the coverage of surface species and interactions between species can also influence the stability of key intermediates, thereby influencing the rate-determining step. In this paper, the kMC method was used to further study the HDMM process from the perspective of kinetics. For complex reactions composed of multiple elementary steps, the concept of degree of rate control (DRC) proposed by Campbell can be employed to conduct sensitivity analysis on the elementary steps of the reaction [80]. DRC is defined as Equation 26S in Supporting Information. KMC method can not only calculate the turnover frequency (TOF) of each elementary step under different temperatures, pressures, and H2-ester ratios but also obtain the change of species coverage, thus helping us to obtain the dominant pathways and rate-determining steps of each substance. 3.2.2 In-depth analysis of the LHHW model The determination of dominant pathways and rate-determining steps can be utilized in the derivation of the LHHW model, whose equations and parameter terms satisfy the following formula [81,82]: (1) r = α T O F = ( kinetic expression ) ( driving force expression ) ( adsorption expressi o n ) Where r represents the reaction rate mol/(s·gcat) of the process, and α is the number of active sites on the Cu-Cr catalyst, mol site/gcat. On the Cu-Cr(111) surface, Cu and Cr are active in response to different species, respectively. Since Cu0 is the main active site of hydrogenation reaction, we define α as the number of Cu atoms per unit mass on the surface of Cu-Cr catalyst [83]. Different catalysts and activation conditions will lead to different α , which can be obtained by N2O-RFC characterization in Supporting Information. The value of the catalyst used in this paper is 5.68 × 10–4 mol site/gcat under the activation condition. The TOF of each reaction is defined as the number of times C4+ products formed per unit time at the unit active site, (1/(s·site)), which can be obtained by kMC calculation. The LHHW model consists of kinetic term, driving force term and adsorption term. Kinetic term is a function of temperature and can be expressed by Arrheniuz formula [82]: (2) K i n e t i c t e r m = α k 0 = α A 0 exp ( − E 0 / RT ) Where k 0 is kinetic factor, 1/(s·site· P a ∑ v f ). A 0 is pre-exponential factor, 1/(s·site· P a ∑ v f ). E 0 is the apparent activation energy, J/mol. R is the gas constant, 8.314 J/(mol·K). The physical meaning of the relevant parameters in the kinetic term is consistent with that in the experimental study of reaction kinetic. The driving force and adsorption terms meet [82,84]: (3) D r i v i n g f o r c e t e r m = ( ∏ p j v f ) − ( ∏ p j v r ) / K P (4) A d s o r p t i o n t e r m = { ∑ K i ( ∏ p j v j ) } m Where p j represents the partial pressure of each substance, Pa. v j , f , r is the coefficient of partial pressure. K i and K P represent the reaction equilibrium constant and adsorption equilibrium constant, respectively, 1/ P a ∑ v j . m is adsorption expression exponent. According to the definition of the reaction equilibrium constant K P [85]: (5) K P = ∏ p j v j = e x p ( − Δ G r RT ) = e x p [ − ( Δ H r RT − Δ S r R ) ] Where Δ G r represents the reaction Gibbs free energy change, J/mol. Δ H r is reaction enthalpy change, J/mol. Δ S r is reaction entropy change, J/(mol·K). Thermodynamic data at different temperatures and pressures can be obtained by DFT calculation, NIST physical properties database, and Aspen software simulation. There is no definite method to calculate the adsorption equilibrium constant K i . Generally, the adsorption equilibrium constant of reactants or products can be determined by temperature programmed desorption experiment. However, this method has a large workload and is easy to be affected by experimental conditions [86]. Combined with the assumptions of steady-state approximation and rate-determining steps of the LHHW model, K i can be derived from Table 4S and Equation 27S ∼ 29S to satisfy the following relations [86,87]: (6) K i = θ i / θ V / ∏ p j v j Where θ i and θ V represent surface species coverage and surface vacancy coverage, respectively, in the range of 0 to 1. Eq. (6) indicates that according to the hypothesis, we can approximate that K i is proportional to the ratio of θ i to θ V when the partial pressure is determined. The reaction equilibrium constant and adsorption equilibrium constant are also functions of temperature and can be expressed as the following equation [88]: (7) { ln ( K P ) = A P + B P / T + C P ln ( T ) + D P T ln ( K i ) = A i + B i / T + C i ln ( T ) + D i T It can be found that the parameters A 0 and E 0 in the kinetic term, A P / B P / C P / D P in the driving force term, and A i / B i / C i / D i in the adsorption term need to be fitted to obtain the LHHW kinetic model. 3.2.3 Building of intrinsic kinetic model by kMC simulation Based on the results of the reaction mechanism and the principles of the LHHW model, a method to construct an intrinsic kinetic model was developed through kMC calculations, which is divided into two parts: model construction (1) ∼ (3) and parameter fitting (4) ∼ (6). The specific construction process was presented in Scheme. 2 . (1) Screening of the dominant pathway and rate-determining step. It is necessary to determine the range of reaction conditions such as temperature, total pressure, and partial pressure applicable to the kinetic equation first. Each reaction shown in Scheme. 1 serves as a unit, kMC calculations of different reaction conditions are performed on the elementary steps obtained by DFT. On the basis of considering the surface diffusion, species interaction, adsorption and desorption, and reaction, the information on TOF and coverage of each elementary step is obtained. Then the dominant pathway to form each product is screened. DRC analysis is performed according to the dominant pathway to rate-determining step under different reaction conditions for the derivation of the LHHW model. (2) Derivation of the LHHW model. The reaction kinetics equations are derived according to the assumptions of steady-state approximation and rate-determining step of the LHHW model [84]. It should be pointed out that different dominant pathways and rate-determining steps may derive different expressions and values of adsorption expression exponent for the same reaction. (3) Simplification of adsorption terms in the LHHW model. The driving force term of the LHHW model includes the partial pressure of the reactants and products, and the adsorption term includes the reactants, products and various intermediate terms. For the pathway composed of many elementary steps, the expression of the model may be very complex (especially the adsorption term), which will have a great negative impact on the difficulty and accuracy of the parameters. The adsorption term can be directly determined by the ratio of surface species coverage to vacancy coverage according to Eq. (6). Therefore, except for reactants and products, such as esters and H*, adsorption terms corresponding to species with very low coverage can be directly ignored [86]. Coincidentally, the kMC simulation provides great convenience in calculating the surface coverage of each species. (4) Optimization solution of coefficient at the same temperature. After the model derivation is completed, the values of the kinetic coefficients k 0 and equilibrium constants K P , K i in the following equations need to be obtained: (8) l n ( TOF ) = l n ( k 0 ) + l n ( ∏ p j v f − ∏ p j v r / K P ) − m l n ( ∑ K i ∏ p j v j ) In the DFT and kMC calculations, the changes of gas partial pressure and total pressure can affect the properties of the reaction system (such as entropy, species adsorption and desorption). However, k 0 , K P , K i in the assumptions of the LHHW model are considered to be the functions of temperature. Although such assumptions can affect the accuracy of the model, this impact is limited in reactor design at larger scales. Therefore, in the case of constant temperature, we approximate that k 0 , K P , K i are constants, which has been applied in many kinetic experimental studies. The reaction equilibrium constant K P can be obtained with the Gibbs free energy change Δ G r at different temperatures. Although the Δ G r can be obtained by Gibbs correction in the DFT calculation, there are errors in the calculation of the small frequency of the gaseous molecules in VASP, which may lead to large gaps between the results of calculation and experiment [89]. The value of Δ G r determines the extent of the reaction. To ensure the accuracy of the model, Δ G r is selected to be obtained through the database of Aspen Plus, where the data may be from experimental experimental measurements or the Benson group contribution method [90]. The UNIFAC method is employed for calculations [91]. The Gibbs reactor model is established in Aspen Plus according to the reactants and products, and the partial pressure of each species after the reaction reached equilibrium is calculated. The K P of the reaction at each temperature point is calculated by Eq. (5). However, due to the complexity of the LHHW model, it is still difficult to obtain accurate solutions for the other coefficients. It is necessary to change the total pressure and partial pressure within the specified range multiple times to calculate the TOF values of the reaction using kMC, and to obtain the value of k 0 , K i at each temperature. In this case, the unconstrained multivariate nonlinear function optimization is implemented through MATLAB, and the function can be selected as [92,93]: (9) f m i n s e a r c h ( errfun , Cof f 0 , Tolfun ) (10) e r r f u n = ∑ i ( ln ( TOF ) fit − ln ( TOF ) kmc ) 2 Where the objective function errfun is calculated in the same way as the residual sum of squares. ln ( TOF ) fit and ln ( TOF ) kmc are the pair values of the solving result and the TOF obtained by kMC calculation, respectively. Cof f 0 serves as the initial search point for the parameter matrix to be solved and needs to be defined by the user. The chi-squared convergence tolerance To l fun is set to 1 × 10–6. An example of the code is provided in the Supporting Information. (1) Fitting of parameter values at different temperatures. After obtaining the kinetic coefficients and equilibrium constants at each temperature, it is necessary to fit the data as a function of temperature to obtain the values of the parameters in Eqs. (3) and (7). For k 0 , a linear fit is applied to ln ( k 0 ) − 1 / T , and the linearity of the data is verified using the R² test. For K P and K i , a unary nonlinear fit is performed on ln ( K i ) − T and ln ( K P ) − T using the Levenberg- Marquardt optimization algorithm, with the convergence chi-squared tolerance set to 1 × 10–9. Outliers (typically with errors exceeding 10 %) have to be ignored to ensure the reasonability of the fitting results [94]. The consistency between the fitting results and the kMC calculations needs to be verified by parity plots and the residual sum of squares (RSS). (2) Calculating initial values of coefficients. Due to the large number of adsorption equilibrium constants K i that need to be solved in Eq. (8), it is difficult to converge the fitting results to the global optimal solution. Even if the global optimal solution is obtained, it is easy to end up with unreasonable parameter values. With limited data points, initial values that are close to the actual conditions are necessary [92]. Therefore, it is important to specify a representative total and partial pressure condition, and obtain initial values for k 0 , K i based on TOF and coverage. The initial values for the adsorption equilibrium constants K i 0 can be quantified by Eq. (6). Based on K P and K i 0 , the initial values for the kinetic terms k 00 can be obtained by Eq. (11). It should be noted that this method may still inevitably obtain unreasonable convergence results, and fine-tuning of the initial values could be used to converge the optimized coefficients to more reasonable values. (11) k 00 = TOF { ∑ K i ( ∏ p j v j ) } m ( ∏ p j v f ) − ( ∏ p j v r ) / K P Through the method outlined in Scheme. 2, it is possible to fit the kinetic models for various reactions in the HDMM process. Although the derivation of the equations is based on ideal assumptions of the LHHW model, kMC calculations help to obtain more accurate information on the dominant pathway and rate-determining step, which enhances the rationality of the model derivation process and the accuracy of the reaction rate calculation results. It should be noted that the development of this method is based on the results of DFT and kMC, and certain simplifications have been adopted during the derivation and fitting process to facilitate the study of complex reaction systems and reactor design. For example, the active sites of the catalyst are simplified as coefficients, which may change as the reaction progresses. The errors in the model are inevitable, and future research should aim to improve the accuracy of the model as much as possible while keeping its form simple. 3.3 Kinetic study of the HDMM process by kMC simulation The dominant pathways and rate-determining steps in the HDMM process were first screened under typical experimental conditions (T = 473K, p = 5.0 MPa, n H 2 : n Reactant = 200 : 1 ) in kMC calculations [5,8,11]. The effects of reaction conditions on properties such as TOF and product selectivity were studied, and intrinsic kinetic models were constructed. The temperature is ranging from T = 433 ∼ 513K, with a gradient of 10K. At each temperature point, the pressure is set to p = 0.1 ∼ 6.0 MPa, and the H2-ester ratio is set to n H 2 : n Reactant = 20 ∼ 350 : 1 . It should be noted that to consider the influence of the product in the reaction, the initial partial pressure of the product is set in the kMC simulations. The wide ranges of pressure and H2-ester ratio result in a significant computational load. Therefore, we have set up 9 groups of corresponding pressure and H2-ester ratio based on previous experimental data, as shown in Table 5S. Lower H2-ester ratios are set at lower pressures, and higher H2-ester ratios are set at higher pressures to ensure the reasonability of the conditions and to maintain the system in the gaseous phase without liquid formation [15]. 3.3.1 Kinetic model construction of DMM hydrogenation Based on the results from Section 3.1.1, kMC simulations were conducted for reaction R1 under typical conditions of T = 473K, p = 5.0 MPa, n H 2 : n DMM : n DMSu = 200 : 0.95 : 0.05 to obtain the reaction network for DMM + H2 → DMSu. It should be noted that DMM cannot be simply represented by the occupation of a single site as large molecules. Therefore, blocking sites were defined to represent large molecules [44]. Upon DMM adsorption, blocking sites are considered to be formed immediately, and no other species can occupy these sites. The blocking sites disappear only after DMSu desorption, as shown in Fig. 11S. The elementary steps include the adsorption and desorption of DMM and DMSu, the dissociative adsorption and desorption of H2, S1∼S2, and H* diffusion. Fig. 8 (a) displayed TOF for each step except H2 dissociative adsorption and H* diffusion, whose TOF values are much greater than those for other steps. It was found that TOF for each step are close (0.038 ∼ 0.039 site-1·s-1), indicating that after DMM is adsorbed on the surface, the two-step C=C hydrogenation occur immediately. Fig. 8(b) presents the 4 elementary steps that have impacts on the formation rate of DMSu. It can be observed that each elementary step promotes DMSu formation at 433 ∼ 513K. DRC results revealed that the hydrogenation of DMMH* has the most significant impact on the formation rate of DMSu. Thus S2 can be considered as the rate-determining step for R1. The TOF value for R1 under typical conditions can be regarded as the desorption rate of DMSu (0.0382 site-1·s-1). Based on the assumption of steady-state approximation and the rate-determining step, the LHHW kinetic equation for C=C bond hydrogenation reaction R1 can be derived, which was presented in Tables 1 and 6S. Fig. 8(c) presents the coverage of species on the Cu-Cr(111) surface at T = 433 ∼ 513K, p = 5 MPa, n H 2 : n DMM : n DMSu = 200 : 0.95 : 0.05 . It can be found that the species coverage decreases with increasing temperature, due to reducing the stability of adsorbed species and accelerating the TOF of intermediate species. Since H2 has a high partial pressure, the coverage of H* generally much higher than that of other species (> 0.2), and thus is not shown. The coverage of H* stabilized at 0.2 ∼ 0.4 from 0.1 ∼ 6.0 MPa. Anger et al. [95] conducted hydrogen adsorption studies on Cu surfaces using monoenergetic H2 beams and obtained a calibrated desorption spectrum indicating a saturated coverage of H* on Cu(111) of 0.5, which indicates that H* is close to saturation adsorption at higher pressures. The coverage of DMM* (0.009) is higher than that of DMMH* and DMSu*, which may be attributed to the larger adsorption energy of DMM. The content of the intermediate DMMH* is relatively low (< 2 × 10–3), indicating that S2 occurs rapidly after the formation of DMMH*. The coverage of DMSu* is the lowest, which may be due to its low partial pressure. Therefore, it can be concluded that the adsorption term K 3 p DMM p H 2 0.5 corresponding to DMMH* can be neglected. The equation could be simplified as: (12) TO F 1 ≈ k 0 ( p DMM p H 2 − p DMSu / K P ) ( 1 + K 1 p DMM + K 2 p H 2 0.5 + K 4 p DMSu ) 2 KMC simulations were conducted for R1 to obtain TOF and coverage values at T = 433 ∼ 513K, p = 0.1 ∼ 6.0 MPa, n H 2 : n DMM : n DMSu = 20 ∼ 350 : 0.95 : 0.05 . The results are listed in Tables 7S and 8S. Execute Step 4 of Scheme. 2, the partial pressures of each species at equilibrium for R1 were calculated using the Gibbs reactor module in Aspen Plus at T = 433 ∼ 513K, and K P at various temperatures were calculated by Eq. (5). At each temperature point, function optimization of Eq. (9) was performed to solve for ln ( TOF ) − p H 2 − p DMM − p DMSu based on the initial values of the coefficients, as shown in Fig. 12S. The k 0 and K i were obtained, and the results are presented in Table 9S. Finally, execute Step 5 of Scheme. 2, linear fitting was carried out for ln ( k 0 ) − 1 / T , and nonlinear fitting was carried out for ln ( K i ) − T and ln ( K P ) − T , as shown in Fig. 13S. The fitting results were substituted into Eq. (13) to obtain the complete rate equation for R1, with the parameters of equilibrium constants listed in Table 2 . (13) r 1 = α 1.018 E − 4 exp ( − 43588 / RT ) ( p DMM p H 2 − p DMSu / K P ) ( 1 + K 1 p DMM + K 2 p H 2 0.5 + K 4 p DMSu ) 2 It should be noted that outliers need to be ignored to ensure the accuracy of the fitting. The parity plots and the residual sum of squares (RSS) of the proposed model for R1 were shown in Fig. 12(a). There is good agreement between the predicted and the kMC simulated rates. Based on the temperature dependence of the rate constants, the apparent activation barrier for R1 is determined to be 43.6 kJ/mol, close to that for the hydrogenation of C=C bonds, which validates the reasonableness of the fitting results [96]. As shown in Fig. 12S, the TOF value for R1 increases with both temperature and pressure. As the pressure increases, the magnitude of the increase in TOF decreases, especially at lower temperatures (< 453K), where TOF hardly increases further under high pressure. Eq. (13) indicates that the reaction orders of DMM and H2 in the driving force term are both 1. The partial pressure of H2 basically equals total pressure under the given H2-ester ratio. However, the TOF value increases only by 4 ∼ 5 times when the total pressure is increased by 60 times. The calculation results may indicate that increasing the pressure does not significantly promote the adsorption and diffusion of H* on the surface. Relatively, as the pressure increases, the partial pressure of DMM also increases, which may accelerate the reaction. The enthalpy change of R1 is -134.1 kJ/mol after Gibbs correction, which is close to the result from Aspen (-126.9 kJ/mol). Analyzing the temperature dependence of reaction equilibrium constant in Fig. 13S, it can be found that R1 is an entropy-decreasing process, and high temperatures are not favorable for the formation of DMSu. 3.3.2 Kinetic model construction of DMSu hydrogenation Fig. 9 (a) showed the reaction network and TOF values of the elementary steps for R2 ∼ R4 at T = 473K, p = 5.0 MPa, n H 2 : n DMSu : n GBL : n MeOH = 200 : 0.95 : 0.025 : 0.025 . It can be found that hydrogenation of ester carbonyl carbon atom is the dominant pathway, with the TOF of S4 being approximately 280 times that of S3 (0.0211 to 1.34 × 10–4 site-1·s-1). S6 hardly occurs due to its high barrier (1.19 eV). C4H7O2-CHO* is barely observed as it rapidly occurs hydrogenation to form C4H7O2-CH2O* (S10). The key intermediate C4H7O2-CH2O* can form MGHB, GBL, and BDO through three pathways: S13, S15 → S16, and S17 → S18 → S19 → S20 → S22, respectively. The formation of C5 esters and GHB was not observed, indicating that both species may occur hydrogenation instead of desorption. According to Equation 24S, the selectivities for DMSu hydrogenation to form MGHB, GBL, and BDO are 0.1 %, 98.0 %, and 1.9 %, respectively. This indicates that DMSu hydrogenation strongly favors the formation of GBL. The TOF for GBL formation is 0.0201 site-1·s-1. Previous studies have shown that the selectivity of DMSu hydrogenation to GBL can exceed 95 % under low pressure, with few reports observing the presence of MGHB [97]. The results confirm that "DMSu adsorption → S4 → S5 → S10 → S15 → S16 → GBL desorption" is the dominant pathway for R3. Fig. 9(b) showed the DRC analysis of the formation rates of MGHB, GBL, and BDO. At T < 513K, S15, which is the cyclization reaction of C4H7O2-CH2O*, has the most significant inhibitory effect on MGHB formation and can be considered as the rate-determining step for R2. However, the rate-determining step for R2 may change to S69 at higher temperatures. For the formation of GBL, S5 has the most pronounced effect and is the rate-determining step for R3. S18 is the rate-determining step for BDO formation. It is worth noting that CH3O* hydrogenation to form CH3OH becomes significant for both R2 and R4 as the temperature approaches 433K, indicating that lower temperatures may be unfavorable to methanol formation. Although kMC results of the DMSu hydrogenation process can be used to fit all kinetic equations for R2 ∼ R4, considering the obvious advantages of GBL formation, the kinetic properties of R3 are more valuable to study. Therefore, the derivation and fitting of the kinetic equation of transesterification reaction R3 were mainly considered, and the results were shown in Tables 3 and 10S. As shown in Fig. 9(c), only 4 species (except H*) had high coverage in DMSu hydrogenation. The coverage of DMSu* is the highest at 433K (0.014), and decreases with the increase of temperature, which may be because high temperature promotes the reaction between DMSu* and H*, and is not conducive to the adsorption of DMSu. The coverage of C4H7O2-CHO-CH3O* increases with the temperature, which may be due to the high temperature aggravating the elementary step S5 reverse. The coverage of CH3O* decreases with the increase of temperature. The coverage of the key intermediate C4H7O2-CH2O* remains at low level, possibly due to its rapid cycling through S15. Therefore, the coverage of other species is much smaller than that of DMSu*, C4H7O2-CHO-CH3O*, CH3O*, and H*, and the corresponding adsorption terms can be ignored. The rate equation can be simplified to: (14) TO F 3 ≈ k 0 ( p DMSu p H 2 0.5 − p GBL p MeOH 2 p H 2 − 1.5 / K P ) ( 1 + K 1 p DMSu + K 2 p H 2 0.5 + K 3 p DMSu p H 2 0.5 + K 7 p MeOH p H 2 − 0.5 ) 2 The kMC simulation of R3 was carried out and theTOF and coverage were obtained at T = 433 ∼ 513 K, p = 0.1 ∼ 6.0 MPa, n H 2 : n DMSu : n GBL : n MeOH = 20 ∼ 350 : 0.95 : 0.025 : 0.025 . According to the linear fitting results, the apparent activation barrier of R3 is determined to be 63.5 kJ/mol, which is close to that of the DMA hydrogenation calculated by Yang et al. [25]. The apparent activation barrier of R3 is larger than that of R1, which indicates that increasing temperature has a more promotion effect on R3.
