(15) states that DMSu and H2 have order of 1 and 0.5 respectively in driving force term. When the total pressure is increased by 60 times, the TOF value of R3 is increased by 5 ∼ 7 times, which indicates that the promotion effect of pressure on reaction R3 is more significant than that of R1. R3 is endothermic, which is consistent with the general transesterification reaction. The reaction heat obtained by DFT calculation is 14.7 kJ/mol, which is close to the result from Aspen (15.0 kJ/mol). It can be found in Fig. 15S that R3 is an entropy-increasing process, indicating that high temperature may be conducive to the formation of GBL from the perspective of thermodynamics. 3.3.3 Kinetic model construction of GBL hydrogenation The research value of discussing the kinetic properties of MGHB hydrogenation is limited. The reaction network for GBL hydrogenation and TOF of elementary steps in R6 ∼ R9 were obtained by kMC calculation as shown in Fig. 10 (a). It is observed that the TOF values for GBL adsorption and H-assisted activation step (S33) are 0.0305 and 0.0301 site-1·s-1 respectively, indicating that 98.7 % of GBL* activated. Upon C3H6O-CHO-r* formation, cleavage of the intra-ring C2-O1 bond may occur to form C2H4-CHO-CH2O* (S34) with a TOF of 0.0289 site-1·s-1. C2H4-CHO-CH2O* forms C2H4-CH2O-CH2O* via S38, while a negligible amount of it forms C2H4-CHOH-CH2O* via S39. One of O atoms in C2H4-CH2O-CH2O* reacts with H* to form C3H7O-CH2O* (S40). Further reaction of C3H7O-CH2O* with H* leads to the formation of BDO* with a TOF of 0.0268 site-1·s-1 (S22). Kikhtyanin et al. [98] investigated their performance in the hydrogenolysis of alkyl esters to produce higher alcohols. The TOF of methyl hexanoate and hexyl hexanoate hydrogenolysis is 0.020 ∼ 0.035 site-1∙s-1 at 483 K and 10.0 MPa. The differences in TOF could be attributed to differences in reactants and reaction pressures. Aubrecht et al. [99] obtained similar TOF in an experiment of dimethyl adipate hydrogenolysis. C3H7O-CH2O* can occur dehydrogenation to form C2H4-CHOH-CH2O* (S20) and GHB* (S44) with TOF of 1.37 × 10–3 and 5.62 × 10–4 site-1·s-1, respectively. Both C3H6O-CHO-r* and C2H4-CHOH-CH2O* can form 2-HTHF* with TOF of 1.73 × 10–3 site-1·s-1. During the simulations, almost no THF formation was observed, which may be attributed to the high barrier for cleavage of the out-of-ring C-O bond in C3H6O-CHO-r*. Based on the results in Fig. 10(a), the dominant pathway for GBL hydrogenation to BDO is "GBL adsorption → S33 → S34 → S38 → S40 → S22 → BDO desorption". The dominant pathway for GHB formation is "GBL adsorption → S33 → S34 → S38 → S40 → S20 → GHB desorption". The dominant pathway for 2-HTHF dominant is "GBL adsorption → S33 → S45 → 2-HTHF desorption". It is proved that the selectivities for BDO, GHB, and 2-HTHF are 89.6 %, 4.6 %, and 5.8 % %, respectively, indicating that BDO will be the dominant product of GBL hydrogenation on the active sites of Cu-Cr catalysts. THF may not directly generate from the hydrogenation and dehydration of GBL but rather from the dehydration of BDO. DRC analysis in Fig. 10(b) showed that S33 promoted the formation of all three products. The rate-determining steps for GHB and 2-HTHF are S33 and S45, respectively. In particular, when T ≤ 483K, S34 has the most significant promoting effect on the formation of BDO and can be regarded as the rate-determining step of R6. When T > 483K, the R6 rate-determining step may change to S33. The result indicates that the rate-determining step of BDO formation changes with temperature. It should be noted that the step with the highest barrier in the dominant pathway of BDO formation is S40 (1.04 eV). However, in kMC simulation, there may be multiple surface H* at Cufcc or Cuhcp sites near the O atom of R-CH2O* group, which improves the chances of S40 occurring. Since the hollow sites are occupied, the ring-opening reaction of C3H6O-CHO-r* may not occur easily. Therefore, the rate-determining step is not necessarily the step with the highest activation barrier. Since GBL hydrogenation mainly forms BDO (R6), which is the target product of the HDMM process, the kinetic equation of R6 is mainly discussed in this paper. The LHHW equation of ester hydrogenation reaction R6 was derived, as shown in Tables 4 and 14S. Due to changes in the rate-determining step, the R6 expression can be divided into R6–1 and R6–2. Based on previous experimental studies on R6, the partial pressure of BDO at equilibrium is much lower than that of GBL under low pressure. Therefore, the partial pressure of BDO is set extremely low to ensure that reaction R6 proceeds in the forward direction in kMC simulation. BDO* adsorbed on Cu(111) surface almost does not occur dehydration reaction, which may be due to the significantly higher barrier of S56 (1.93 eV) than S2-Cr (1.26 eV). The differences in the adsorption energy and reactivity of BDO*-Cr and BDO* result in the absorption rate of BDO*-Cr (2.38 × 10–3 site-1∙s-1) is higher than that of BDO* (1.59 × 10–4 site-1∙s-1). The TOF value of THF formed by BDO*-Cr dehydration is 1.67 × 10–3 site-1∙s-1, which is about 16 times smaller than that of BDO formation (R6) under the same conditions. Simultaneously with THF formation from BDO*-Cr dehydration, H2O*-Cr is directly formed and desorbed. N-BuOH is mainly derived from the stepwise dehydration mechanism of BDO at the Cr site. BDO*-Cr first occurs S3-Cr, and C3H6O-CH2* and OH*-Cr occur hydrogenation reaction to form n-BuOH* and H2O*-Cr, respectively. The dominant pathway of BDO dehydration to THF (R10) is "BDO adsorption → S2-Cr → THF desorption". The dominant pathway of n-BuOH formation is "BDO adsorption → S3-Cr → S67 → n-BuOH desorption". THF* formed by direct dehydration mechanism can desorption directly from the Cutop site, and C3H6O-CH2* formed by stepwise dehydration mechanism will occupy the hollow site on Cu(111) surface, which will undoubtedly be affected by H* diffusion. Therefore, the activation barrier cannot fully reflect the kinetic properties of the reaction. Although the activation barrier of S2-Cr (1.26 eV) is close to that of S3-Cr (1.32 eV), the selectivity of formation of THF and n-BuOH is 87.8 % and 12.2 %, respectively. DRC analysis in Fig. 12(b) showed that desorption of S2-Cr and H2O*-Cr promoted the formation of both products. The rate-determining step for generating THF and n-BuOH are S2-Cr and S3-Cr, respectively. However, due to the extremely large value of K P , temperature may have little impact on the equilibrium composition of R10. 3.3.5 HDMM process influenced by reaction conditions It can be found that the HDMM process on the Cu-Cr catalyst can be simplified into a consecutive reaction model dominated by R1 → R3 → R6 → R10. The product distribution of the HDMM process is determined by the kinetic properties of these four reactions. The rate of reaction R1 is greater than that of the other reactions. Therefore, after DMM is adsorbed on the active site of Cu-Cr(111), the C=C bond reacts hydrogenation with one molecule of H2 to produce DMSu rapidly, which is proved by almost 100 % of the conversion of DMM in the products of HDMM experiments [8,11]. BDO is the main product during GBL hydrogenation on the active sites of the Cu-Cr catalyst (R6), but the formation of THF is also inevitable inevitable since it comes from BDO. Until now, there have been few reports in literature or patents on catalysts with BDO selectivity exceeding 90 % [8,11,102], which supports the results. The LHHW model can be used for subsequent studies of the reactor design and also provides an intuitive understanding of the kinetic and thermodynamic properties of reactions. Fig. 13 showed the changes of TOF and equilibrium compositions for each reaction under different conditions. TOF is the most direct indicator reflecting reaction rate. Fig. 13(a) indicates that under consistent pressure and H2-ester ratio, the order of TOF is R1 > R3 ≈ R6 >> R10. Turek et al. [8] observed that DMM forms DMSu rapidly, which further reacted to produce GBL and BDO along with CH3OH. In addition, a small amount of THF and trace amounts of n-BuOH. The product distribution partially validates the correctness of the TOF values at different temperatures. As the temperature increases, the reaction rates become faster, with the rate of R10 increasing the most significantly due to its highest apparent activation barrier. When T ≤ 478K, R6 > R3; when T > 478K, the rate of R3 is faster, indicating that temperature has more pronounced promoting effect on R3. Fig. 13(b) showed the variation of the molar ratios of products and reactants for each reaction with temperature, calculated at the equilibrium composition when TOF is 0. R10 can proceed almost completely, so n T H F / n B D O is not discussed. It can be observed that n G B L / n D M S u is not significantly affected by temperature, while n D M S u / n D M M and n B D O / n G B L decrease significantly. The order of magnitude of n D M S u / n D M M is above 10, DMM can be almost completely hydrogenated to DMSu. The value of n B D O / n G B L is approximately 1 ∼ 14, indicating that the equilibrium composition of BDO is significantly affected by temperature. It can be found that low temperatures favor the formation of BDO, while high temperatures favor the formation of GBL and THF. Fig. 13(c) and (d) discussed the influence of total pressure on the reactions. From the analysis of the driving force terms, the reaction orders of R1, R3, R6, and R10 are 2, 1.5, 1.5, and 1, respectively. However, it can be found that the degree to which total pressure promotes the reaction rates is similar, possibly due to the different influences of the adsorption terms on the reactions. Pressure has a significant effect on the equilibrium composition of R6. At 473K and n H 2 : n G B L = 200 : 1 , the range of n B D O / n G B L at equilibrium increases from approximately 0.0013 to 5 as the total pressure increases, indicating that only at high pressures can more BDO be formed. At low pressures (especially near 0.1 MPa), the amount of BDO at equilibrium will be three orders of magnitude less than that of GBL. Fig. 13(e) and (f) displayed the effects of H2-ester on the reactions. It can be found that as H2-ester increases, the TOF values of all reactions decrease, with R10 showing the largest decrease, indicating that a high H2 partial pressure can inhibit the side reaction of BDO dehydration. Overall, high temperatures favor the formation of GBL and THF but are unfavorable for the formation of BDO. High pressures favor the formation of BDO. High H2-ester ratios favor the inhibition of THF formation. Therefore, if GBL is the target product, the reaction should be carried out at high temperature and low pressure. If BDO is the target product, the reaction should be carried out at low temperature, high pressure, and high H2-ester ratio. If THF is the target product, the reaction should be carried out at high temperature. These conclusions have been verified in previous experimental results [5,8,11], indicating that the findings of this study are reasonable from a qualitative perspective. 4 Conclusions This study constructed the Cu-Cr(111) surface model composed of the Cu(111) surface and the Cr4O6 cluster. The reaction mechanism and kinetic properties of the HDMM process were investigated through multi-scale simulation method combining DFT and kMC. DFT calculations indicated that the HDMM process initiates with the C=C bond hydrogenation in DMM. Hydrogenation of ester compounds such as DMSu, MGHB, and GBL primarily occurs on the Cu(111) surface, and H-assisted activation of the ester carbonyl group can lower the activation barrier for C-O bond cleavage in ester. Cr sites with Lewis acidity can lower the barrier for C-O bond cleavage in BDO, thereby enabling BDO to form THF and n-BuOH. KMC calculations constructed the reaction network for the HDMM process under typical conditions. The dominant pathways for the hydrogenation of esters in HDMM are carried out through the hydrogenation of ester carbonyl carbon atom mechanism. DMSu hydrogenation can potentially form MGHB, GBL, and BDO, with GBL dominating. DRC analysis revealed that the rate-determining step for GBL hydrogenation to BDO is GBL* + H* → C2H4-CHO-CH2O-r* when T ≤ 483K, and the ring-opening step C2H4-CHO-CH2O-r* → C2H4-CHO-CH2O* when T > 483K. The formation rate of THF from BDO is one order of magnitude higher than that of n-BuOH. In general, Cu0 sites are the active center for hydrogenation, while Cr-O-Cu sites are the active centers for dehydration on the Cu-Cr catalyst. The method for constructing a reaction kinetic model based on the reaction network has been developed. The LHHW model is derived from the reaction network obtained by DFT and kMC. The model is carried out with unconstrained nonlinear optimization and linear/nonlinear fitting using TOF and coverage data to obtain parameters of kinetic coefficients and equilibrium constants. The intrinsic kinetic equations of R1 DMM + H2 → DMSu, R3 DMSu + 2H2 → GBL + 2CH3OH, R6 GBL + 2H2 → BDO, and R10 BDO → THF + H2O in the HDMM process were obtained, respectively. The apparent activation barriers follow the order: R1 (43.6 kJ/mol) ≈ R3 (39.8/49.5 kJ/mol) < R6 (63.5 kJ/mol) < R10 (130.2 kJ/mol). The kinetic and thermodynamic properties of the reactions were analyzed by varying the reaction conditions. As temperature and total pressure increase and the H2-ester ratio decreases, the reaction rates increase. R6 is a typical equilibrium-controlled reaction that is significantly influenced by temperature and pressure. The higher the temperature, the smaller the equilibrium constant for R6 and the lower the composition of BDO. If BDO is the target product, the reaction should be carried out at a low temperature, high pressure, and high H2-ester ratio. In conclusion, this study completes the detailed reaction mechanism of the HDMM system based on first principles. An attempt has been made to bridge the gap from reaction mechanism to reaction engineering and from microscopic to mesoscopic scale through multi-scale simulation. It should be noted that the established intrinsic kinetic model cannot fully reflect the details contained in the DFT and kMC studies. Besides, the variability and difficulty in quantifying active sites are issues that must be addressed. However, the model comprehensively incorporates both the kinetic and thermodynamic properties of the reactions, providing theoretical support for further studies on reaction behavior in reactors and the design of isothermal bed reactors. coredata.dc:description: 1,4-Butanediol (BDO) is a fine chemical raw material that plays a significant role in the production of degradable plastics. The hydrogenation of dimethyl maleate (HDMM) to BDO is a highly favored technology the industry for its low-cost catalysts and high selectivity. However, the kinetics equation and optimal conditions for HDMM process to BDO on copper-chromium catalysts are still unclear, which has hindered the development of the design of advanced industrial reactors and production processes. Herein, the Cu-Cr(111) surface model was constructed by combining DFT and kMC to investigate the reaction network of the HDMM process. The analysis of the activation barrier and Bader charge revealed that Cu0 and Cr act as the active centers for ester hydrogenation and alcohol hydroxyl cleavage, respectively. The dominant pathways and key intermediates for the formation of γ-butyrolactone (GBL), BDO, and tetrahydrofuran (THF) were claimed by TOF and coverage analysis. Changes in the rate-determining step with temperature for BDO formation were observed by the concepts of degree of rate control. Based on the reaction network, a method was proposed to construct the intrinsic kinetic equation models, which are subjected to nonlinear optimization and linear/nonlinear fitting to obtain relevant parameters. Analysis of the kinetic and thermodynamic properties of reactions in the HDMM process revealed that the higher temperature and total pressure, the lower H2-ester ratio, the higher reaction rates, and different products have different responses to the reaction conditions. Optimal conditions were determined to target different products. This study attempted to span from the microscale to mesoscale, providing theoretical support for novel reactor design for the HDMM process and possibilities for studying the kinetic properties of C4+ complex reaction systems through multi-scale simulation.
